title: Why is the Japanese diet so healthy? | BBC Good Food
author: Nicola Shubrook
description: Is a diet of fish, veg and fermented food responsible for Japan's impressive health and longevity? Discover the benefits of traditional Japanese food.
cleaned_text: Why is the Japanese diet so healthy? Discover the benefits of traditional Japanese food. The Japanese have long been revered and studied for their long life expectancy, which is [higher than almost anywhere else in the world](https://www.macrotrends.net/countries/JPN/japan/life-expectancy). So why is the traditional Japanese diet so healthy and what do they eat? We asked registered nutritionist Nicola Shubrook. What is the traditional Japanese diet? The traditional Japanese diet is largely fresh and unprocessed, with very few refined ingredients and sugar. In fact, it isn't that dissimilar to a traditional Chinese diet, with staples including rice, cooked and pickled vegetables, fish and meat. However, because Japan is actually a group of islands (all 6,852 of them), its residents consume a lot more fish compared to other Asian countries. They also eat raw fish in sushi and sashimi, plus quite a few pickled, fermented and smoked foods. What are the components of a traditional Japanese diet? [Soya beans](/glossary/soya-beans-glossary), usually in the form of [tofu](/howto/guide/ingredient-focus-tofu) or fresh edamame, are a key part of the Japanese diet, along with other beans such as [aduki](/glossary/aduki-bean-glossary). Fermented soy bean products such as [miso](/howto/guide/health-benefits-miso) and [natto](https://www.japantimes.co.jp/life/20od/youll-either-love-or-hate-those-stinky-sticky-beans/#.WRCLNonytTY) are popular staples. Natto is traditionally consumed at breakfast and has a [beneficial effect on the gut](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4101585/) and supports blood clotting. The Japanese also consume a wide variety of land and sea vegetables including [seaweed](/howto/guide/health-benefits-seaweed), which is packed full of health-boosting minerals, and [may help to reduce blood pressure](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/releases/231490.php). Fruit is often consumed with breakfast or as a dessert, especially Fuji apples, tangerines and persimmons. Alongside their diet, the Japanese are big fans of [green tea](/howto/guide/health-benefits-green-tea) - in particular matcha tea, which is fast gaining popularity elsewhere, including the UK. Matcha, a stone-ground powdered green tea, is most valued for its high antioxidant compounds known as catechins, which [have been linked](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28292023) to fighting cancer, viruses and heart disease. What are the benefits of the traditional Japanese diet? A [study by the British Medical Journal](https://www.bmj.com/content/352/bmj.i1209) found that those who stuck closer to the [Japanese dietary guidelines](https://www.fao.org/nutrition/education/food-based-dietary-guidelines/regions/countries/japan/en/) - a diet high in grains and vegetables, with moderate amounts of animal products and soy but minimal dairy and fruit - had a reduced risk of dying early from heart disease or stroke. As their diet is traditionally high in soy and fish this may also play a significant role in [reduced risk of cardiovascular disease](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28430815). The Japanese also have the lowest rates of obesity among men and women as well as long life expectancy. The island of Okinawa, in southernmost Japan, has the [highest number of centenarians in the world](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3259160/) as well as the lowest risk of age-related diseases (for example diabetes, cancer, arthritis and Alzheimer's). This has partly been [attributed to their traditional Japanese diet](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5403516/), which is low in calories and saturated fat yet high in nutrients, especially phytonutrients including flavonoids, found in different coloured vegetables. This also includes [phytoestrogens](/howto/guide/ingredient-focus-soya), or plant-based oestrogens, that [may help protect](https://jn.nutrition.org/content/132/10/3168.short) against hormone-dependent cancers, such as breast cancer. The diet of the Okinawan people has been little influenced by the dietary changes of the Western culture, which have been seen in more urban Japan. Which healthy eating behaviours are part of traditional Japanese culture? Traditionally, the Japanese tend to have a healthy attitude to food and eating. They have a saying, "hara hachi bu", which means to eat until you are 80% full, and it's not uncommon to teach children this philosophy from a young age. The way the Japanese serve their food is also key. Rather than having one large plate, they often eat from a small bowl while enjoying several different dishes, usually rice, miso, some fish or meat and then two or three vegetables dishes, often served communally and eaten in rotation. The Japanese are also strong believers in 'flexible restraint' when it comes to treats and snacks, enjoying them from time to time but in smaller portions. Japanese recipe inspiration...
